p: Heroin varies in physical and chemical characteristics by production source [ 10]. To the west of the Mississippi River heroin is mostly available as a solid form (i.e., Mexican-sourced “black tar” [BTH]. “Powder heroin” (PH) is predominant east of the Mississippi River and although the source is changing from Colombian to Mexican, heroin form remains predominantly the same: powder [ 2, 11]. Besides an ecological association between HIV prevalence, incidence, and geographic prevalence of BTH ( Fig 1), these contrasting source-forms vary in physical state, cold/hot water solubility, pH, heat stability, weight/volume, and purity [ 6]. These chemical features could provide mechanistic insight into the factors associated with differences in HIV incidence.
